body: In powerlevel10k [show on command](https://github.com/romkatv/powerlevel10k/blob/master/README.md#show-on-command) is very popular. Almost no one toggles prompt parts manually. I'm sure starship users would love it, too.

That would be even nicer! üëç 
Still, a toggle would be save me quite a bit of time already (and is probably easier to implement?)

While not exactly what you are looking for the ability to modify the configuration from the command line was added in [v0.41.0](https://github.com/starship/starship/releases/tag/v0.41.0) via #1095.

So you to enable and disable modules by running a command e.g
```bash
# Disable the kubernetes module
starship config kubernetes.disabled true
# Enable the kubernetes module
starship config kubernetes.disabled false
```

With a bit of scripting/aliasing this might be a viable alternative for now.

issue.title: Consider add Toggle Support in Advanced Configuration to able to do toggle modules and features

repository.name: starship
repository.description: ‚òÑüååÔ∏è  The minimal, blazing-fast, and infinitely customizable prompt for any shell!

issue.body:
## Feature Request

#### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
Let's imagine we have a custom `starship.toml` configuration like this:

```toml
# ~/.config/starship.toml

[kubernetes]
format = 'on [‚õµ $context \($namespace\)](dimmed green) '
disabled = false
```
‚Ñπ: _I will be used _Kubernetes_ example in this issue._

So, notice that we always have to see that module till manually disabled from file by _hand_. Even we really do not need to see it, use it, etc, we really need a toggle function in [Advanced Configuration](https://starship.rs/advanced-config/).

```
on ‚õµ dev-stage-local.idc (dev) ~/.config took 3m6s
```

It is really annoying that every time we have to see this. Just instead of: `~/.config` Isn't it? Thus, ever time when I need to see more information about that specific module, I have to toggle `disabled` flag in configration file.

#### Describe the solution you'd like
What about _Toggle Aliases_?

```toml
[kubernetes]
format = 'on [‚õµ $context \($namespace\)](dimmed green) '
disabled = false
toggle_alias = 'k8s!'
```

Which means that, this module should always be started as disabled when terminal being started, as you think.

If we want to start dealing with some _Kubernetes_ stuffs any time, any where, we can simply call `k8s!` _alias_, in order to toggle `(disabled=!disabled)` that module's active status for _current terminal session only_.

body:
@andytom Would you like any help with this issue? Since I'm Rust rookie, not making any promises but I'd be interested in looking into it. Are you OK with suggested solutions here?

Since these alternatives are good solutions, but still some lack of usabilities. All of these (included this issue) are just targets of flag `disabled`. What about other _custom_ flag _toggle-abilities_.

```bash
$ starship toggle <module>
$ starship config toggle <module>
$ starship toggle config <module>
```

-or-

Should we concern for any other flags instead of just `disabled`? 

```bash
$ starship config toggle git_branch.only_detached
$ starship config toggle nodejs.display_private
```

@Dentrax, sorry for the delay in replying, just don't seem to have enough time at the moment. Please feel free to have a go don't worry about being a new to Rust we all have to start somewhere üòÑ.

I would be a bit hesitant to add another use to the `config` sub-command as we already use it it for updating the config file via the cli and opening the config file in an editor. So maybe add a new sub-command `toggle` with a usage something like

```
$ starship toggle MODULE_NAME [OPTION]
```

`MODULE_NAME` would just be the name of the module e.g `nodejs` or `kubernetes`

`OPTION` would be an optional argument that toggling different like `only_detached`, if not set it should default to `disabled`.

What do you think?

@andytom That's sounds good! Will our brand new `toggle` command look like this eventually?

The `toggle` command feature will only work for `boolean` values. Throws error otherwise?

```rust
       .subcommand(
            SubCommand::with_name("toggle")
                .about("Toggle a given starship module")
                .arg(
                    Arg::with_name("name")
                        .help("The name of the module to be toggled")
                        .required(true),
                )
                .arg(
                    Arg::with_name("value")
                        .help("The value of the config to be toggled")
                        .required(false),
                        .required_unless("name")
                 ),
        )
```

i.e.:

```bash
$ starship toggle kubernetes # default: 'disabled'
$ starship toggle git_commit only_detached # override default config key to: 'only_detached'
```

> @andytom That's sounds good! Will our brand new `toggle` command look like this eventually?

Yes that LGTM.

> The `toggle` command feature will only work for `boolean` values. Throws error otherwise?

Yes, the toggle should only deal with bools, everything else should use the `starship config ...` command.

issue.title: feat(command): add 'toggle' command

repository.name: starship
repository.description: ‚òÑüååÔ∏è  The minimal, blazing-fast, and infinitely customizable prompt for any shell!

issue.body:
Closes #894

Signed-off-by: Dentrax <furkan.turkal@hotmail.com>

#### Description
See the given issue in order to get more description about the `toggle` feature.

#### Motivation and Context
As requested at #894 and #1873, this PR adds brand new `toggle` command.

#### Screenshots (if appropriate):
[![asciicast](https://asciinema.org/a/374476.svg)](https://asciinema.org/a/374476)

#### How Has This Been Tested?
* Given module name and flag key exist without arg:
```sh
$ dasel select -f ~/.config/starship.toml -p toml -m '.kubernetes.disabled' # returns 'true'
$ cargo run toggle kubernetes
$ dasel select -f ~/.config/starship.toml -p toml -m '.kubernetes.disabled' # returns 'false'
```
* Given module name and flag key exist with arg:
```sh
$ dasel select -f ~/.config/starship.toml -p toml -m '.kubernetes.disabled' # returns 'true'
$ cargo run toggle kubernetes disabled
$ dasel select -f ~/.config/starship.toml -p toml -m '.kubernetes.disabled' # returns 'false'
```
* Given module name exist but flag key not exist with arg:
```sh
$ cargo run toggle kubernetes show_namespace
```
_See the error:_ `[ERROR] - (starship::configure): Given config key 'show_namespace' must be exist in config file`
* Given module name and `non-boolean` flag key exist with arg:
```sh
$ cargo run toggle kubernetes format
```
_See the error:_ `[ERROR] - (starship::configure): Given config key 'format' must be in 'boolean' format`
* Given module name not exist:
```sh
$ cargo run toggle winamp
```
This will panic-ed, it works the same as the `update_configuration()` function. We just ignored the `None` case, by using this: `table.get(keys[0]).unwrap()`. Shouldn't we cover the case of `None`? What about adding a new fatal message like: ``[ERROR] - (starship::configure): Given module 'winamp' not found in config file``
* Given module name and flag key not exist:
```sh
$ cargo run toggle winamp volume
```
Same as above.

- [X] I have tested using **MacOS**
- [ ] I have tested using **Linux**
- [ ] I have tested using **Windows**

#### Checklist:
_Some help wanted here too! :)_
- [ ] I have updated the documentation accordingly.
- [ ] I have updated the tests accordingly.

**Happy aliases, you astronauts! **

`alias k8s!='cargo run toggle kubernetes'`
